sentence.text: V-1 both arms showed cubitus varus deformity.
Proximal and middle phalanges were missing.
Distal non-functional phalanges with intact nails were present.
Post-axial polydactyly was observed in left hand.
Humerus was short; ulnae and radii were bowed and deformed.
Lower limbs showed short femurs, tibia and fibula.
Both feet had metatarsus adductus deformity (Fig. 3c).The right foot was mildly club shaped in supernatant form (Fig. 3a).
Radiographic analysis of affected member showed normal skull, trunk region and spinal cord.
Pelvic region showed deformities including femoral head epiphysis (left femur head displaced from acetabulum), very short or missing femoral neck region, and femur head showing coxa vulga deformity.
Obturator foramen and pelvic inlet (superior aperture) were normal (Fig. 3f).
Knee joints were dislocated and showed fixed flexion deformity.
Radii and ulna were deformed with right arm showing dislocated ulna head.
In the affected member V-1, carpals and metacarpals were completely fused having no connection with the phalanges.
Proximal and intermediated phalanges were missing; only non-functional distal phalanges were present (Fig. 3g).
Tibia and fibula were very short, completely fused and deformed.
Tarsals, metatarsals, tibiotalar joints, calcaneum, navicular, cuboid and cuneiform bones were completely fused (Fig. 3h).
The affected member had normal trunk, skull, facial structure and eyesight.
